pros: I enjoyed the students and the facilities.
cons: Low pay and school is struggling with enrollment.
Pay and research funds way, way too low for the workload, and fell way short of even comparison schools. College needs a clear identity and direction. Board of Trustees is a bit too over-involved.

job_title: Fitness center receptionist in Indianola, IA
pros: easy work, very very flexible hours, choose your own hours
cons: not super interactive supervisor, face to face exposure during covid

pros:
Working with students is so much fun! They are great to keep you young! 

 Campus has gotten a much needed improvement in the last few years.
cons:
I worked in the Admissions Office and can't recommend it. When it all boils down, being an admissions counselor is a sales job so you have all of the travel, goals and pressure with none of the pay. I heard more than once from the President that admissions counters are a dime a dozen so they aren't worth a decent wage. When I was there, we had to work our standard 8 hours in the office then make calls to prospective students at night. In addition there were many of weekends for visit days and such. All for a barely livable wage.

The admissions leadership is in desperate needs of a house cleaning. They insist on doing things the way it has always been done and refuse to adapt to the millennial generation. They need to bring in all new leadership or accept that the counselors will never meet their goals. 

If you are a student just out of college, it can be fun to get to travel and be on the road with other admissions counselors but it gets old quick. There is no way you can do with job with a significant other, let alone kids since so much time is demanded of you. Simpson needs to learn about flex hours and how to properly treat admissions counselors or they will continue to have to constantly hire because of turnover.

pros: Feels close knit, easy to form connections, benefits
cons: Not immune to drama, poor pay and very limited ways to increase pay

review_title: The students are awesome, the pay is not.
pros: I loved getting to work with students on a daily basis. They were energetic and fun and kept the engagement up. Many of the staff are also wonderful.
cons:
Leadership is disconnected from the outside world. They have such a closed minded mentality. I worked in the Admissions office and they were unwilling to change to adapt to the new ways to recruit students. We were basically directed to call them to death when millennials don’t want to talk on the phone. 

They need to realize that you either adapt to the times or the school will die. I feel like Simpson will be one of the first private schools to close in the state because they are so unwilling to adapt and change. It’s sad because it is a good school with great alumni, fantastic location and solid facilities.

pros: Great small school with excellent facilities
cons: Faces competition from similar small private schools in the midwest

review_title: Great experience to take with you into the real world.
pros: flexible work hours and pleasant staff
cons: low pay rate and sometimes no room to advance
No cons to share. Overall great place to work and learn.

pros: Worked with great people and students
cons: Wasn't quite like family as they lead you to believe

pros: Great co workers and team work
